fields.descriptive_line: Proof poster advertising The Three Lives of Lucie Cabrol, devised by Theatre de Complicite based on a story by John Berger.  Intended for the performances at the Riverside Theatre, Hammersmith, 23 February- 9 April 1994, but not including the name of the theatre or all the sponsors' details, which appear on S.748-2000.
fields.physical_description: Poster printed in lime green and orange featuring a large palm print in orange, and small silhouette images in white and green of four posturing figures, and in orange and green, two chickens.  Black lettering, vertically down the right hand edge, gives the name of the company, with the title of the play, details of the authors and production team, the dates and the Daily Telegraph quote: 'Spell-binding... quite exceptional originality', centre. Logos on the poster show that the production won the Prudential Award for Theatre, 1993, and include those of The London Arts Board and The Arts Counmcil.
fields.history_note:
Proof of the poster produced to advertise The Three Lives of Lucie Cabrol, Riverside Theatre, Hammersmith, 23 February - 9 April 1994, a Theatre de Complicite production based on a story by John Berger, adapted by Simon McBurney and Mark Wheatley.  Directed by Simon McBurney; designed by Tim Hatley; lighting by Paule Constable, sound by Christopher Shutt.  The Company comprised Lilo Baur, Simon McBurney, Hannes Flaschberger, Hélène Patarôt, Christine Marx, Stefan Metz, Tim McMullan and Mick Barnfather.  The poster features a logo showing that the production was a Prudential Award for Theatre winner, 1993  but does not include all the other sponsors' logos that appear on S.738-2000.  In 1995 this production was as the Shaftesbury Theatre, 18 Jan-25 February;  Liverpool, Everyman, 27 Feb-4 March; Blackpool Grand Theatre 20-25 March; Bury St. Edmunds, Theatre Royal, 28 March-1 April; Newcastle Playhouse, 5-8 April; Paris, Theatre Des Bouffes Du Nord 12-22 April, and Bournemouth Festival, Poole, 25-27 May. In April/May 1995 the production also visited Munich, Basel, Berlin, Hamburg and Helsinki, and between September and December 1995 went to Johannesburg, Tokyo, Perth, Melbourne and Sydney.

Historical significance: The Three Lives of Lucie Cabrol was a Theatre de Complicite production which opened at the Manchester City of Drama Festival at the Dancehouse Theatre, 12 January 1994. The narrative of the story was based on the life of a peasant woman from the Haute Savoie, whose story was told originally to the author John Berger by friends from the region.
fields.production_note: Attribution note: This poster is an incomplete version of S.748-2000. It is printed with the dates of the performances at the Riverside Theatre, 23 February-9 April 1994, but it does not have the name of the theatre, or all the sponsors' logos which appear on the final state poster.
